A quadrilateral in the plane has vertices $(1, 3)$, $(1, 1)$, $(2, 1)$ and $(2006, 2007)$. How many square units is the area of the quadrilateral?
inference:
The quadrilateral has vertices (1, 3), (1, 1), (2, 1), and (2006, 2007).  We can divide the quadrilateral into two triangles. The first triangle has vertices (1, 3), (1, 1), and (2, 1).  The second triangle has vertices (1, 1), (2, 1), and (2006, 2007).
The first triangle has base length 1 and height 2.  Its area is (1/2) * 1 * 2 = 1 square unit.
The second triangle has vertices (1, 1), (2, 1), and (2006, 2007).  We can use the determinant formula for the area of a triangle with vertices $(x_1, y_1)$, $(x_2, y_2)$, and $(x_3, y_3)$:
Area = (1/2) |x1(y2-y3) + x2(y3-y1) + x3(y1-y2)|
Plugging in the coordinates of the second triangle (1, 1), (2, 1), and (2006, 2007), we get:
Area = (1/2) |1(1-2007) + 2(2007-1) + 2006(1-1)|
Area = (1/2) |1(-2006) + 2(2006) + 2006(0)|
Area = (1/2) |-2006 + 4012 + 0|
Area = (1/2) |2006|
Area = 1003 square units.
The total area of the quadrilateral is the sum of the areas of the two triangles: 1 + 1003 = 1004 square units.
